summary: This is the U.S. Government's omnibus opposition memorandum to Ghislaine Maxwell's twelve pre-trial motions in her criminal case (S1 20 Cr. 330). It argues against motions to dismiss based on Epstein's Non-Prosecution Agreement, statute of limitations, pre-indictment delay, suppression of evidence, dismissal of perjury counts, severance, insufficiency of indictment, striking surplusage, multiplicity, and various disclosure requests. The document details the Government's legal arguments and factual background regarding the investigation and charges.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Charged with six counts including conspiracy to entice and transport minors for illegal sex acts and perjury. The Government opposes her pre-trial motions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier. Alleged co-conspirator with Maxwell in sex trafficking scheme. His 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement with the Southern District of Florida is a central topic.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Signs the memorandum as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, representing the Government.

persons.name: Virginia Roberts Giuffre
persons.context: Referred to as Jane Doe #3. Filed a defamation lawsuit against Maxwell in 2015. Her allegations and the subsequent depositions form the basis of the perjury counts.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Founder of Boies Schiller, the law firm that represented Giuffre in the civil defamation suit against Maxwell. The defense alleges improper coordination between his firm and the Government.

persons.name: Maria Villafaña
persons.context: Former prosecutor with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida (USAO-SDFL) who negotiated the Epstein NPA. Cited in the OPR report regarding the scope of the NPA.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who signed the Epstein NPA.

persons.name: Andrew Oosterbaan
persons.role: Chief, Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section
persons.context: Department of Justice official consulted by USAO-SDFL during the Epstein investigation, per the OPR report.

persons.name: Kenneth Starr
persons.context: Epstein's defense attorney who protested parts of the NPA after its execution.

persons.name: Stan Pottinger
persons.context: Attorney for Giuffre who, along with Brad Edwards and Peter Skinner, met with AUSA-1 in February 2016.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney for Giuffre who participated in the February 2016 meeting with AUSA-1.

persons.name: Peter Skinner
persons.context: Attorney with Boies Schiller who arranged the February 2016 meeting with AUSA-1.

persons.name: Ross Gow
persons.context: Spokesman for Maxwell who called Giuffre's claims 'untrue' and 'obvious lies,' leading to the defamation lawsuit.

persons.name: Colleen McMahon
persons.context: Chief Judge of the SDNY who granted the Government's application to modify the protective order in the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case to allow compliance with a grand jury subpoena.

persons.name: Sarah Netburn
persons.context: Magistrate Judge who denied a similar Government application to modify a protective order in a different civil case (Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein).

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: Judge who ordered the unsealing of Maxwell's deposition transcripts in the civil case, a decision affirmed by the Second Circuit.

persons.name: Robert W. Sweet
persons.context: Deceased judge who originally presided over the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case and entered the protective order.

persons.name: Minor Victim-1
persons.context: One of the minor victims identified in the indictment. First interviewed by law enforcement in September 2019.

persons.name: Minor Victim-2
persons.context: One of the minor victims identified in the indictment. Allegedly received an unsolicited massage from Maxwell.

persons.name: Minor Victim-3
persons.context: One of the minor victims identified in the indictment. First interviewed by law enforcement in August 2019. Her experiences, while partly time-barred for substantive counts, are alleged as part of the conspiracies.

persons.name: Michael Casey
persons.context: Deceased individual described as the 'agent' of Minor Victim-1. The defense claims his testimony would have been exculpatory.

persons.name: Joseph Recarey
persons.context: Deceased Palm Beach Police Department detective involved in the prior Epstein investigation. The defense claims his testimony would have been exculpatory.

connections.description: Alleged co-conspirators in a scheme to recruit, groom, entice, and transport minor girls for sexual abuse by Epstein.
Maxwell was the defendant in a civil defamation lawsuit filed by Giuffre, which led to the depositions that are the basis of the perjury charges.
Boies's law firm represented Giuffre in her civil litigation against Maxwell.
Villafaña was the lead prosecutor for the USAO-SDFL who negotiated the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement with Epstein.
Pottinger, along with other attorneys, met with an AUSA in February 2016 to present information about Epstein. There was also a May 2016 phone call.
Maxwell is alleged to have groomed and facilitated the abuse of this minor victim by Epstein.
Maxwell is alleged to have groomed and facilitated the abuse of this minor victim by Epstein, and is specifically charged with giving her an unsolicited massage.
Maxwell is alleged to have groomed and facilitated the abuse of this minor victim by Epstein in London and elsewhere.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein enters into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, immunizing him from federal prosecution for specified crimes and purportedly immunizing potential co-conspirators.

events.title: Giuffre Files Defamation Lawsuit
events.description: Virginia Roberts Giuffre files a civil defamation lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell in the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Meeting between Attorneys and AUSA
events.description: Attorneys Stan Pottinger, Brad Edwards, and Peter Skinner meet with an AUSA from the SDNY (AUSA-1) to present information about Jeffrey Epstein, advocating for an investigation.

events.title: Maxwell's First Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is deposed by Giuffre's attorneys in the civil defamation case. Her testimony forms the basis for Count Five (perjury) of the indictment.

events.title: Maxwell's Second Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is deposed a second time by Giuffre's attorneys. Her testimony forms the basis for Count Six (perjury) of the indictment.

events.title: SDNY Investigation Opens
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York formally opens its investigation into Epstein and possible co-conspirators, prompted by Miami Herald reporting.

events.title: Court Modifies Protective Order
events.description: Chief Judge Colleen McMahon grants the Government's ex parte application to modify the protective order in Giuffre v. Maxwell, allowing Boies Schiller to comply with a grand jury subpoena for civil discovery materials.

events.title: Epstein Indicted by SDNY
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is indicted on federal sex trafficking charges by the SDNY. He was arrested on July 6, 2019.

events.title: Minor Victim-3 Interview
events.description: Minor Victim-3 first agrees to be interviewed by law enforcement from the SDNY.

events.title: Minor Victim-1 Interview
events.description: Minor Victim-1 first agrees to be interviewed by law enforcement from the SDNY.

events.title: Maxwell Indicted
events.description: A grand jury sitting in White Plains, SDNY, returns a sealed indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Superseding Indictment
events.description: A grand jury returns a superseding indictment against Maxwell with ministerial corrections.

events.title: Maxwell's April 2016 Deposition Unsealed
events.description: Following an order by Judge Preska affirmed by the Second Circuit, Maxwell's April 2016 deposition transcript is publicly filed.

keyFacts: The Government argues Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with the Southern District of Florida does not bind the Southern District of New York, does not immunize Maxwell, and she lacks standing to enforce it as a third party.

The Government contends the indictment is timely under 18 U.S.C. § 3283, which extends the statute of limitations for crimes involving sexual abuse of a minor to the life of the victim, and that the 2003 amendment applies retroactively to pre-enactment conduct where the limitations period had not yet expired.

The Government details its process of obtaining civil discovery materials via a grand jury subpoena to Boies Schiller and a subsequent court order modifying the protective order, rejecting defense claims of Fourth, Fifth, and Due Process violations.

The Government opposes severance of the perjury counts (Five and Six) from the substantive sex trafficking counts (One through Four), arguing they are logically connected, involve overlapping evidence, and severance would require victims to testify twice.

The Government defends the use of a grand jury sitting in White Plains, arguing it was proper (especially during the pandemic) and that the defendant's fair cross-section challenge fails because the relevant community is the counties from which the White Plains jury wheel is drawn, not Manhattan.
